awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Earth-Abundant Transition Metal Photosensitizers Using Ligand-to-Metal Charge Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Carsten Milsmann of the Department of Chemistry at West Virginia University is investigating a new class of early transition metal complexes that are promising candidates for the development of molecular photosensitizers due to their interesting optical and electrochemical characteristics. Molecular photosensitizers find application in a wide variety of solar energy applications including photovoltaics, solar fuel production, and photocatalysis.  The goal of these research efforts is to provide access to photoactive compounds based on readily-available, earth-abundant metals that can improve upon and/or replace currently available technology based on precious metals. This will further the development of more cost-efficient solar energy applications for which scalability is not hindered by the limited availability of the metal component. The project requires expertise in the fields of inorganic, physical, and organic chemistry and is ideally suited for the training and education of highly qualified scientists at all levels. Outreach activities aimed at middle school students in rural areas of West Virginia will be conducted in collaboration with the West Virginia University Center for Excellence in Science Education and support efforts to train the next generation of science teachers in the state.

The electron-deficient nature of early transition metals requires new approaches to initial charge separation via absorption of a photon compared to the well-established functional principles of electron-rich precious metal photosensitizers. This project investigates ligand-to-metal charge transfer processes to convert light energy into chemical potentials. Through a combination of synthetic chemistry, spectroscopic studies, and quantum-chemical calculations this project are answering the following questions: 1)What are the fundamental design principles to generate long-lived excited states in early transition metal complexes? 2)How can systematic modifications of the supporting ligand framework be used to fine-tune the optical and electron transfer properties of the complexes? 3)Can the photo-induced electron transfer properties of early transition metal complexes be utilized to enable transformations requiring highly reducing conditions (e.g. dinitrogen reduction)?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In this project funded by the Chemical Mechanism, Function and Properties (CMFP) program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Professor Carsten Milsmann and his research team at West Virginia University developed new molecular photosensitizers based on Earth-abundant early transition metals and main group elements. Photosensitizers are revolutionizing a wide range of important technologies including solar cells for renewable energy production, light-emitting diodes (LEDs) for energy-efficient display applications, photo(redox) catalysis for fine chemical synthesis, and minimally-invasive biomedical applications like photodynamic therapy and biosensing. One particular drawback of existing photosensitizer technology is a reliance on rare and precious metals, which have dominated the field of molecular inorganic photochemistry for decades. Aside from the obvious economical downsides reflected in high costs and low resource availability, precious metals often more toxic than their more Earth-abundant counterparts, resulting in environmental and human health issues.

 

Over the course of this 5-year project, the Milsmann group developed a new class of photosensitizers using cheap and abundant elements such as zirconium, hafnium, silicon, and germanium. Because the chemical properties of these elements are fundamentally distinct from those of precious metals, different mechanisms of charge separation upon exposure to light were utilized in these newly developed molecules. Most importantly, it was shown for the first time that photo-excited states with significant ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) character can engage in facile electron- and energy-transfer steps. A second seminal outcome of this project was the first report of thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) in systems with LMCT excited states. This mechanism of photoluminescence is uncommon in precious metal photosensitizers, which typically emit light through phosphorescence. With these fundamental insights in hand, the Milsmann group was able to show that their newly developed zirconium photosensitizers are able to replace, and in some cases outperform, precious metal compounds in photoredox catalytic applications, photon upconversion, and photocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction.

 

Chemical control over the photophysical and electrochemical properties of photosensitizers is imperative to further improve performance-critical parameters and provide tailor-made molecules for any given application. With this in mind, the Milsmann group was also able to show how systematic modifications to early transition metal photosensitizers allow predictable changes in their chemical stability, optical properties, and electrochemical potentials. Extension of these design strategies from high-valent group 4 elements in the d-block of the periodic table to other tetravalent elements of the p- and f-block were also initiated during the 5-year funding period. These fundamental studies will provide more detailed insight into chemical and physical trends within the periodic table of elements and offer new directions for future photosensitizer development.

 

This research project directly addressed several important themes including the growing demand for renewable energy production, the need for efficient synthetic routes to pharmaceuticals and other fine chemicals, and a reduction of the reliance on rare and expensive natural resources that often have to be sourced from foreign markets. The conducted studies were interdisciplinary and encompassed aspects of synthetic inorganic and organometallic chemistry, studies of (photo)physical properties, and applications in catalysis and solar energy conversion. Collaborations between researchers from 5 different US universities and national labs were developed over the course of the 5-year project and generated 14 peer-reviewed research articles to date. The PI and his coworkers also provided more than 30 professional scientific presentations at universities (domestic and international) and scientific conferences and workshops with national and international reach. The investigations fostered the scientific education and professional development of 5 different graduate students and 1 postdoctoral researcher. To date, 2 chemistry-based doctoral dissertations have been completed with partial financial support from this award, and 2 more are expected to be finalized within the next two years. In addition, this NSF award provided resources for 2 WVU undergraduate researchers who conducted research experiences focused on the development of educational resources. In coordination with the WVUteach Initiative, that provides Secondary STEM Education teacher preparation pathways for undergraduate students, these two students completed projects required to obtain their STEM teacher’s certifications in the Milsmann group. These projects explored opportunities to incorporate experiments involving luminescence phenomena into the K-12 curriculum. Outcomes were presented at the annual conference of the West Virginia Science Teachers Association (WVSTA).


Last Modified: 10/16/2024
Modified by: Carsten Milsmann
